column1: The Withywindle was a minor tributary of the River Baranduin that flowed through the Old Forest on the borders of the Shire.
File:Mark Fisher - Withywindle.pngThe river began in the Barrow-downs and flowed southwest through the Old Forest until merging with the Brandywine. The Dingle
column3: was said to be the heart of all the strange happenings in the Old Forest.

column1: The river flowed into Brandywine at the south Buckland. At the mouth of the Withywindle
column4: a guarded hythe - or haven - that was beyond the protection of the High Hay
column5: and had a fence extending into the water.

column2: there was the small village of Breredon between the Haysend of the High Hay and the Brandywine. The Elvet-isle in the Withywindle was home to swans.

column5: and at the end of every summer he would go along the river to gather water-lilies for her. He was on his last trip of the year when he encountered the Hobbits.

column1: When Frodo Baggins and his companions entered the Old Forest on 26 September 26
column2: they found themselves drawn toward the Withywindle valley despite their intentions
column3: and on the banks of the river they encountered Old Man Willow
column4: an ancient tree whose hatred of all peoples who walked free on the earth permeated the woods. The Hobbits were lulled to sleep by Old Man Willows spell.  Frodo was pushed into the Withywindle and was held under by the willows roots until Samwise Gamgee saved him
column5: and Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took were trapped inside Old Man Willow.  They were rescued by Tom Bombadil.

column1: The word withy means "willow" (common element in English place-names) and windle means "spindle" or "reel" and is supposed to be translation from Hobbitish.

David Salo has suggested it represents a speculative Old English for *Withigwindel. He noted that the natural Old English interpretation of such a noun would have been "twisted willow (branches)" referring to "a basket made of willow-branches" rather than the winding shape of the river.

column2: the name is also a word-play of the word "Withywind"
column5: a harmful weed that twines itself around other plants. The word withywind means "flexibly strong
